intro.heading: Why Use a Gratuity Calculator
paragraphs: Gratuity is a statutory post-employment benefit that many salaried employees receive when they leave a job after qualifying service.
Calculating the exact amount — especially when partial years, rounding rules and tax limits come into play — can be confusing.
A Gratuity Calculator converts your last drawn basic salary (plus dearness allowance) and completed years of service into an accurate gratuity estimate in seconds.
It helps you check eligibility, plan finances at retirement or resignation, and estimate how much of the payout will be tax-exempt.
The tool saves time, removes arithmetic mistakes, and shows assumptions (like rounding rules and statutory caps) so you can approach your employer or HR with clarity.

whatIs.heading: What is Gratuity? — Gratuity Policy & Who Qualifies
paragraphs: Gratuity is a lump-sum payment made by an employer to an employee as a reward for long and continuous service, governed in India by the Payment of Gratuity Act, 1972 for covered establishments.

Under the Act, an employee becomes eligible for gratuity after completing five years of continuous service; the five-year rule is waived in cases of death or permanent disablement resulting from injury or illness.

The benefit is typically calculated using the employee’s last drawn basic salary plus dearness allowance and the number of years of service; some employers offer more generous schemes but cannot pay less than the statutory minimum.
The Act and subsequent amendments also specify a maximum statutory ceiling on gratuity paid to qualifying employees.

formula.heading: Gratuity Calculation Formula — How the Math Works
formula.intro: The standard statutory formula used for employees covered under the Payment of Gratuity Act, 1972 is as follows:

methods.title: Formula (for employees covered under the Act):
formulas: Gratuity = (15 / 26) × Last Drawn Salary (Basic + DA) × Years of Service

definitions: 15/26 represents 15 days’ wages out of a 26-working-day month.
Last Drawn Salary = Basic Salary + Dearness Allowance.
Years of Service = Total completed years of service (fractions rounded as per employer or Act guidance).
formula.note: For establishments not covered by the Act, employers often follow the rule of half a month’s salary per year of service, though terms may differ. Gratuity is also subject to a statutory maximum limit as prescribed under the law.

inputs.heading: What inputs you need — Ordered Checklist for the Gratuity Calculator
inputs.intro: To get an accurate gratuity estimate, have the following ready (enter in this order):
list: Last drawn basic salary + Dearness Allowance (DA) — monthly amount.
Total years of continuous service — include completed years; note rounding rules.
Date of joining and date of termination — for precise service calculation (optional).
Reason for termination — normal retirement/resignation, death or disability (death/disablement may waive the 5-year rule).
Whether your establishment is covered under the Payment of Gratuity Act (most organisations with 10+ employees are).
Any employer policy that pays more than statutory gratuity (optional).
inputs.note: Enter these values and the calculator will display the statutory gratuity, any cap/ceiling adjustments, and the taxable portion.

taxation.heading: Taxation, Ceiling & Legal Limits — What’s Tax-Exempt and What’s Capped
paragraphs: The Payment of Gratuity Act sets the computation method, and the government has increased the statutory ceiling on gratuity payable to ₹20 lakh through the Payment of Gratuity (Amendment) Act and subsequent notifications.

For tax purposes, the exemption on gratuity under the Income Tax Act is determined as the least of: (a) actual gratuity received, (b) gratuity calculated under the statutory formula (15/26 × salary × years), or (c) the prescribed monetary ceiling (currently ₹20,00,000).
Government employees may have different rules for gratuity payment and taxation, governed by their respective service conditions.

Because both the payable ceiling and tax exemption limits have changed over time, the Gratuity Calculator highlights the statutory ceiling and indicates the likely tax-exempt portion, helping you plan withdrawals and tax reporting effectively.

notes.heading: Notes & Caveats
points: The statutory formula applies to employees covered under the Payment of Gratuity Act; employers not covered by the Act may follow alternate but typically similar formulas — always confirm with HR or your employment contract.

The government amended the Act to raise the gratuity ceiling to ₹20 lakh; tax exemption rules also reference this cap — check official notifications or tax guidance for the current effective limits before filing returns.
